Introduction

All NHS services are required to fulfil their legal duty under section  of the Children Act 2004 and statutory responsibilities as set out in Working Together to Safeguard Children  Therefore, safeguarding and promoting the welfare of children must be an integral part of the care offered to all children and their families by all health care professionals working within acute services. This may be care offered to children, young people, families or adults who are parents or carers.

Many of the inquiries into child deaths and serious incidents involving children have demonstrated serious failings in the effectiveness of professionals. This has been in part attributed to not receiving appropriate supervised support. The National Service Framework for Children, Young People and Maternity Services (section 14.1, 2004) advocates that “consistent, high quality supervision is the cornerstone of effective safeguarding of children and young people”.

Working to ensure children are protected from harm requires sound professional judgments to be made. It is demanding work that can be distressing and stressful and those involved must have access to advice and support from professionals experienced in the field of safeguarding children.

Effective supervision promotes good standards of practice. This policy has been written to be consistent with national and local policies and procedures, in particular, Southend Essex Thurrock (SET) Safeguarding and Child Protection Procedures (2019) and Working Together to Safeguard Children (2018)

The Mid and South Essex (MSE) university hospitals group attaches the greatest importance to the provision of adequate support and guidance to its employees, thereby enabling them to develop their skills and experience to an appropriate level and practice safely. It acknowledges also the importance of ensuring employees who work with children, young people and their families will develop their skills in effective practice and thereby enhance the process of learning from experience. This is vital in order to meet the differing needs of service users, trust employees and supports both service and clinical development.
Scope

The purpose of this policy is to set out the MSE Group's arrangements for, and approach to, the provision of effective Safeguarding Children Supervision for clinical staff. The policy recognises the need to clearly identify the difference between clinical supervision, midwifery supervision and safeguarding children supervision as clinical and midwifery supervision does not fall within the scope of this policy.

Clinical supervision is a “formal process of professional support and learning which enables individual practitioners to develop knowledge and competence, assume responsibility for their own practice and enhance consumer protection and safety of care in complex situations” (DOH 2004).

Safeguarding Children Supervision is more focused in its approach and only concerned with issues to support staff members to ensure that they are competent to safeguard and promote the welfare of children.
This policy applies to all staff employed by the Trust who work predominantly with children and their families. Case holding staff members will require one to one safeguarding supervision
Paediatric Medical Staff

It is a core competency for all clinical staff working with children to undertake regularly documented reviews of practice1, including Peer Review. It is a component of the Clinical Governance Framework and is expected by the judiciary, GMC and professional bodies.
https://www.rcpch.ac.uk/sites/default/files/Peer_review_in_safeguarding.pdf

The purpose of a Peer Review is to provide a proactive culture of learning, professional development and support, education and training, case supervision, service improvement and improvement of multiagency processes. The purpose is also to provide support in a non-hierarchical environment, decrease professional isolation, to share best practice and foster understanding of the complexities of situations. Regular attendance at Peer Review is expected for all medical staff working closely with children and young people, as Peer Review provides the safeguarding supervision function for these clinical staff members.

The Named Paediatrician for Safeguarding Children will lead the Peer Review sessions for Paediatric Consultants and Paediatric junior doctors who should also attend for training and development purposes. Peer Review sessions will be held as a minimum six times a year on the three hospital sites and a record of attendance and the focus of the meetings should be held by the lead consultant and the individual practitioners in attendance for evidence.
Paediatricians can also access ad hoc supervision from the Named Doctor on request.
Other Medical staff and Junior Doctors are supervised by their educational and clinical supervisors.

Consultant staff can access supervision from the Named Doctor on request. Ad hoc supervision regarding the management of individual cases (e.g. advice regarding appropriate actions or in support of challenging partner agencies) is available as needed from the Named Doctor, Named Nurse or the Safeguarding Team, as per Good Practice Recommendations for Peer Review in Safeguarding(RCPCH2012) https://www.rcpch.ac.uk/sites/default/files/Peer_review_in_safeguarding.pdf

The content of this policy does not preclude any practitioner from seeking advice from any named Trust Safeguarding Professional or Children's Social Services if they have concerns for the safety or well being of a child at any time.
Definitions

table_items.text: An accountable process which supports assures and develops the knowledge, skills and values of an individual, group or team. Its purpose is to improve the quality of their work to achieve agreed outcomes (Providing Effective Supervision: Skills for Care & CWDC 2007). It is central to the process of learning and to the expansion of the scope of practice and should be seen as a means of encouraging self-assessment and analytical and reflective skills (NHSME A Vision for the Future, HMSO 1993).

The Safeguarding Children Team is available for advice by telephone regarding any safeguarding children issues which practitioners wish to discuss. Additionally, staff can make individual appointments with the Named or Specialist Nurses for Safeguarding Children if they have concerns about a child or family Accessing Safeguarding Children Supervision as required is particularly useful for practitioners where there are situations of an urgent nature and clinicians need immediate guidance and support.

The main purpose of a child protection Peer Review is to develop a proactive culture of learning about process, diagnosis and management and to support doctors who are undertaking child protection work. Peer Review provides the opportunity for professional development and support, education and training, case supervision, service improvement and improvement of understanding of and engagement with multiagency processes.

data.text: Roles and Responsibilities
Role & Responsibilities within the Trust (Committees) Duties are:
Site Clinical Governance Committee monitors compliance with Safeguarding Children policies and processes;
MSE Safeguarding Children Committees oversee all operational safeguarding children activity including training compliance and adherence to policies;

MSE Group Adult and Child Safeguarding Committee in common is a strategic meeting to: Check and challenge that MSE systems and processes are fit for purpose to safeguard vulnerable individuals, focus on all services but not be operational, oversee CQC requirements and facilitate discussion relating to external strategic issues that may impact on MSE Group.
Chief Executive – The Chief Executive as Accountable Officer has overall responsibility for the quality and safety of services provided by the Trust.
Site Director of Nursing/Medical Director will be corporately responsible for the implementation of this policy. This includes:
When the policy is reviewed and updated incorporating the time frame for the process to be undertaken;

Reporting into the necessary governance committees; ensuring that MSE provides/supports the training for staff to discharge their responsibilities and that there is an appropriate competency framework to support this;
The Director of Nursing for SUH site also holds the executive lead in relation to Safeguarding Children.

Heads of Nursing/Head of Midwifery/Matrons/Heads of Departments/Service Managers/Department Managers – are responsible for the implementation of this policy at department level. This includes: Identifying training needs and ensuring staff attend training; assessing service requirements against what the service is delivering.
Designated, Named Professionals and the Safeguarding Team - Lead personnel have a key role in championing the importance of safeguarding and promoting the welfare of children throughout MSE.

All staff are responsible for adhering to and complying with the requirements of the policies, procedures, guidelines and protocols contained within and applicable to their area of operation. All employees have a duty to safeguard children by recognising abuse and neglect and referring onwards as required (Working Together 2018).
Individual Accountability

The process of supervision is underpinned by the principle that each practitioner remains accountable for their own practice and as such their own actions within supervision. Safeguarding children supervision does not replace nor should it delay the individual's responsibility to make a referral to statutory agencies where there are concerns that a child may be suffering or likely to suffer from significant harm. In such cases staff should refer to the SET Child Protection Procedures
Organisational Accountability

Under Section 11 of the Children Act 2004 all health care organisations have a duty to make arrangements to safeguard and promote the welfare of children and young people, and to cooperate with other agencies to protect individual children and young people from harm.
4.8.1 The organisation must ensure that staffs who work predominantly with children, young people and adults who are parents/carers have access to safeguarding children supervision.

4.8.2 The MSE Group will ensure that those practitioners providing supervision are adequately trained in supervision skills and have up to date knowledge of the legislation, policy and research relevant to safeguarding and promoting the welfare of children. This must reflect the requirements set out in Working Together (2018), Safeguarding children and young people and roles and competences for health care staff Intercollegiate Document (2019)
Supervisor Responsibilities
All safeguarding children supervisors will ensure that they:
Have received professionally recognised supervision skills training (e.g. NSPCC) and ensure that their knowledge remains current through relevant course updates and accessing relevant literature;
Have up to date knowledge in legislation, policy and research relevant to safeguarding children;
Be accountable for the advice that they give;
Ensure those receiving mandatory safeguarding children supervision have agreed a supervision contract with the supervisor (appendix 1).
Identify when they do not have the necessary skills/knowledge to safely address issues raised and redirect the supervisee accordingly
Discuss management of individual safeguarding children cases to explore and clarify the management and thinking relating to the case.
Share information knowledge and skills with the supervisee
If required, constructively challenge any personal and professional areas of
concern
Supervisee Responsibilities
The Supervisee has a responsibility for:
Being adequately prepared for supervision and ensuring that all relevant information is available inclusive of health records for each child or family member concerned;
Clearly identifying areas of concern to be discussed;
Contacting the supervisor should any difficulties with attendance occur;
Maintaining a record of supervision they attend in accordance with their own professional and personal development;
Ensuring that any plans, targets and objectives formulated and agreed during supervision are adhered too;
Respect other participants view point if in a group setting;
Communicating outcomes that pertain to changes to the child's/ren's care plan with other relevant health professionals as appropriate.

4.10.1 Each health professional is accountable for their own individual clinical practice. Through supervision whether scheduled or ad hoc, if the clinician feels that they should refer to Children's Social Services, procedures as outlined in the MSE Child Protection Procedures should be followed
Supervision Process
To ensure that services are delivered competently and effectively to children and families and that the needs and protection of children is of paramount importance:
To improve decision making in child in need/child protection work;
To clarify roles and responsibilities;
To ensure the health and well being at work issues are addressed;
To ensure that staff are managed, supported and developed;
To enhance professional development;
To assure service users and their carers that the organisation is accountable for local practice standards and nationally set standards;
To ensure financial governance and probity.

To ensure that safeguarding children practice is consistent with the Local Safeguarding Children Partnerships and the Trust's organisational procedures. With respect to individual cases, safeguarding children supervision can help practitioners to keep a focus on the children, to avoid any delay in action to maintain objectivity and to address the emotional impact of the work.
Support and Guidance to Staff
Safeguarding Children supervision will:
Provide the opportunity for discussion of personal experience and the testing of ideas incorporating reflective practice.

Enable the practitioner to express both positive and negative feelings which they may have towards cases. Consideration should be given to the effect of fear or anxiety on current work and perceptions. Discussion and sharing of responsibility will help to reduce stress and anxiety in practitioners.
Ensure that safeguarding children practice is consistent with Southend, Essex and Thurrock Safeguarding and Child Protection Procedures (SET Procedures) and associated policy documents.
Allow the discussion of inter-professional relationships with team members and professional colleagues.
Standards for Supervision

All NHS services are required to fulfil their legal duty under section  of the Children Act 2004 and statutory responsibilities as set out in Working Together (2015)8 .Working Together (2015)9 and the Accountability and Assurance Framework (2015)10 outlines that safeguarding supervision should be an integral part of practice for all health care practitioners but particularly for named and designated professionals within their role of supporting other professionals in their agencies to recognise the risk to children .

As a minimum case-holding staff will receive safeguarding children supervision every three months but more frequently if required. For key groups inclusive of Paediatric, Neonatal, Children's Services and Paediatric Emergency Department - safeguarding supervision will be offered throughout the year. It is expected that staff working within these groups will attend safeguarding supervision no less than two times per year but more frequently if required (Appendix 1).

It is a core competency for all clinical staff working with children to undertake regularly documented reviews of practice, including Peer Review. It is a component of the Clinical Governance Framework and is expected by the judiciary, GMC and professional bodies.

Peer Review is an established model of safeguarding supervision for clinicians and regular attendance at Peer Review is expected for all medical staff working closely with children and young people (RCPCH 2012). Peer Review sessions are facilitated by the three MSE Named Consultant Paediatricians for Safeguarding Children and will be held as a minimum six times a year on each of the three hospital sites.

Agency and temporary staff will receive safeguarding children supervision as required if they are working directly with children with a child protection issue or with parents who have children where there is a child protection concern.

Following specific case supervision a record of the supervisory discussion along with a plan of action will be recorded on the child or expectant's mother's electronic/paper record to ensure other practitioners are made aware of any concerns.
The length of each safeguarding supervision session and frequency of attendance should be determined on an individual basis taking into account the Supervisee's needs.

All staff who receives regular supervision will complete a written agreement with their Safeguarding Children Supervisor. This agreement will identify the roles and responsibilities of both the supervisor and supervisee. The supervisee will receive a written summary of their supervisory session of which they should keep a copy and a copy should be available to Line Managers upon request.

Safeguarding Children Supervision usually takes place on a one to one basis but may also be undertaken by a group when ‘members come together in an agreed format to reflect on their work by pooling their skills, experience and knowledge in order to improve both individual and group capacities' (Morrison 2005).

Safeguarding children supervision is mandatory for all designate, associate designate and named professionals. Effective mandatory safeguarding children supervision needs to be regular (not less than quarterly) and provide continuity, so the relationship between supervisor and supervisee develops.

Safeguarding children supervision sessions must be held in a suitable environment where confidential discussion can take place. Adequate protected time must be allowed for effective supervision to take place and interruptions only allowed for urgent situations.
Escalation of Concerns

Problem resolution is an integral part of professional co-operation and joint working to safeguard children. Concern or disagreement may arise over another professional's decisions, actions or omissions in relation to a referral, an assessment or an enquiry. It is important to resolve difficulties quickly and openly by identifying areas in working together where there is a lack of clarity to promote resolution.

The safety and focus of individual children are the paramount consideration in any professional disagreement and unresolved issues should be escalated to their line manager/safeguarding lead with due consideration to the risks that may exist for the child. Where children's services practitioners are concerned or in disagreement with their colleague relating to the safeguarding of a child they should seek advice from the Designate/Associate and Named Safeguarding Children Professionals to promote resolution.
Documentation and Record Keeping

A group or individual supervision contract must be agreed as appropriate by the Supervisor and all the Supervisees at the start of engaging in supervision sessions (Appendix 1). The Supervisor should keep a copy, all the Supervisees should keep a copy and a copy should be available to Line Managers upon request.
Where possible the supervisee will ensure that children's records are available to the supervisor when they seek supervision relating to individual children.

The supervisor and supervisee will agree how and where safeguarding children supervision records will be stored and what will be recorded within health records on an on-going basis. In cases where the supervisor does not make an entry into the health record s/he will make a summary of the Safeguarding Children Supervision with clear action plan indicating responsibility for each action. A copy should be held securely by the Supervisor and Supervisee. (Appendix 3). Where follow-up supervision sessions are arranged, documentation from the previous session will be made available for further discussion or closure.
Training Requirements

All practitioners' delivering Safeguarding Children Supervision must have completed training in the supervision process and should have undertaken the NSPCC Child Protection Supervision Course or its equivalent and ensure that their knowledge remains current through relevant course updates and accessing relevant literature. In addition further training should be undertaken to meet the competency levels set out in Working Together (2018) and the Intercollegiate Document (2019).
Monitoring and Audit
Monitoring of adherence with this policy is required to ensure compliance with:
Section 11 Audit;
Outcome 7 Care Quality Commission Essential Standards.
Compliance will be monitored through key performance indicator data supplied to the CCG and monitored through Safeguarding Children Team.
Compliance with other requirements of this policy will be audited on an annual basis by the trust's Named Nurse and reported to relevant Quality & Governance Committees.

data.text: Approval and Implementation
The policy will be subject to approval at both the Group Integrated Child and Adult Safeguarding Committee and the Site Operational Paediatric Safeguarding Committees.
The policy will be ratified by the Joint Document Management Group and uploaded to the Trusts' Intranet.

It is the responsibility of each department to ensure that where manual copies of documents are kept and relied upon that these are always up to date and that the old version is routinely removed. The policy will be accessible on the site intranet. The policy will be promoted through relevant internal meetings, MSE communications and signposted within safeguarding training.
Equality Impact Assessment

This Policy has been the subject of an Equality Impact Assessment. The output of the assessment demonstrates that no-one as a consequence of this policy is placed at a disadvantage over others. (Refer to Appendix 4)

Appendix 2:
Safeguarding Supervision Contract
SAFEGUARDING CHILDREN SUPERVISION CONTRACT

Supervision in  safeguarding  children is a  formal  process  of professional  support  and learning  which  enables  and  empowers  practitioners  to  develop  knowledge  and competence,  assume  responsibility  for  their  own  practice  and,  therefore,  enhance safeguarding children by assisting them to review, plan and account for their safeguarding work.

Supervision enables both the supervisor and the supervisee to reflect on, scrutinise and evaluate  clinical  practice  and  is  both  educative  and  supportive  whilst  facilitating  the supervisee to explore their feelings about the work and the family. Safeguarding Children Supervision takes place in a safe environment and optimises its potential for maintaining effective practice in child protection.

The process of supervision is underpinned by the principle that professionals remain accountable for their own practice and the Supervisor will be accountable for the advice and  guidance  given  or  action  they  take.  All  professionals  should  adhere  to  their professional code of practice.

Individual supervision will centre on children/families in the medium and high priority categories e.g. a discussion and analysis of children with Child Protection or Child in Need Plan, and those children and families with any vulnerability/needs causing concern for the practitioner.
Additionally  practitioners  may  bring  to  supervision  cases  regarding  vulnerable children/families where there are difficulties in assessing the level of risk.

Safeguarding Children Group Supervision is a planned group discussion that promotes reflection and learning on safeguarding issues or theme. Groups may be made up of staff working in the same teams or from different teams or areas of work.

As a supervisee I agree to:

As a supervisor I agree to:

Make time available for supervision to be booked in advance Document the agreed summary of the discussion with clear action plan indicating responsibility for each action. A copy should be held securely by the Supervisor and Supervisee.
